proposals.reasoning: With so little information on Mission 1, I want a team that minimizes the chance of accidentally picking two evil players while still giving us something to read from the outcome. Alice is the leader and strongly vouched for herself, and multiple people (including Diana and myself) have already floated Alice+Eve as a sensible low-risk pair. This combo fits the early-game preference for a conservative, relatively safe team that the group has been circling around, while also letting the rest of the table react to and analyze a straightforward, standard first mission choice.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and with no strong suspicions yet, a simple Alice+Eve team is a reasonable low-info Mission 1 that most people are treating as relatively safe.
Doesn’t include me or either Merlin-claim candidate (Charlie/Diana), so it gives weak info and ignores the alternative pairings I’ve been pushing for.
My evil teammate is on a 2-person team, giving us both influence and the option to control the early information.
Neither Alice nor Eve is known evil to me, and this is a low-risk, standard Mission 1 team that fits earlier table discussion.

I’m on the team, and early mission participation gives evil flexibility to either pass for trust or sabotage later, while the composition looks reasonable enough not to draw suspicion for my approval.
I don’t like auto-including the leader on Mission 1 and I’d rather see a more neutral pair like Bob+Diana first for better info and less early anchoring on Alice.

discussion.content: We’ve got almost no info yet, so the safest start is a conservative team—I’m obviously going to vouch for myself, and I’d pair with someone who’s been acting calm and consistent so far, maybe Bob, so we minimize early sabotage risk.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I’d actually rather pair with either Charlie or Diana instead of just auto-trusting Alice this early. Getting at least one of them on an early clean mission gives us a better anchor for reads later.
I’d like to be on the first team, and I lean toward pairing with Bob—starting with a non-Alice duo gives us a different info thread than the usual “leader auto-includes themself + most trusted.”

I’d rather start with a lower-risk pair like Alice and Bob or Alice and Eve—putting Charlie on the very first team feels a bit hasty when we’ve got no clears yet. Early missions are mostly about reducing sabotage odds while we gather reads.
I kind of like Diana’s safer approach for Mission 1—something like Alice + me keeps the odds of a double-evil team low while still giving us a starting point to read reactions and results.

With this little info I’d rather not auto-include the leader, so I’d lean toward something like Bob + Diana for Mission 1 as a relatively “neutral” pair. If we *do* include Alice, I’d pair her with Bob over Charlie for now.

proposals.reasoning: We should keep exactly one of Alice/Eve from the successful first mission, and add two new players for information. Charlie has drawn some suspicion for pushing to include himself while excluding Eve, and Diana’s preferences conflict with several others’ views, so I’m avoiding both for now. I know I’m good, so including myself reduces the risk of stacking unknowns. Alice + Bob + Frank keeps one member from the clean mission, tests Bob as a fresh read, and anchors the team with someone I know is loyal to Good.

votes.comment: I’m on the team and we keep exactly one from the successful mission while testing two new players; even if it fails, it gives us good info on Bob/Frank early.

Team excludes both Merlin candidates (Charlie/Diana) and Frank deviated from his earlier preference for including Diana, which feels suspicious. I’d rather see a team with exactly one of Alice/Eve plus one of Charlie/Diana for better info.

I don’t like both Diana and me being sidelined after only one mission; this keeps Alice from the clean team but swaps in two untested players, including the leader himself, which feels like we’re locking in a narrow read too early instead of spreading information.
No known evil is on the team, and keeping exactly one member from the successful first mission while testing two new players is a solid info-gathering strategy.
All three are likely good; as an unseen player I prefer a team with more uncertainty or including myself.
Includes me (known good to myself) plus Alice from a clean mission and one new player (Bob), giving solid info with limited risk.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice + Eve) succeeded with 0 fails, which slightly raises both of our village equity but doesn’t clear either of us, since a single spy can always choose to pass early. For Mission 2, I want (1) exactly one member from the successful team, to preserve some continuity, and (2) two new players, to maximize information gain without overloading the team with unknowns. The main competing suggestions were: (a) Alice + Bob + Charlie, and (b) Alice + Bob + Diana. Multiple players (Diana, Frank) expressed concern that Charlie specifically pushed to remove Eve while keeping himself in, which is mildly suspicious. Bob and Diana both argued for the structural idea of exactly one of Alice/Eve plus two new players, and Frank independently converged on Alice + Bob + Diana. Between Charlie and Diana, Diana has attracted less suspicion so far and didn’t push to place herself on the team as strongly as Charlie did. Frank also seems reasonable but cannot be included without dropping Bob or Diana and losing some of the consensus structure that’s built up. Therefore I choose Alice + Bob + Diana as a balanced, information-rich team that keeps one prior success member, incorporates two fresh reads, and avoids the player (Charlie) currently under the most suspicion from multiple others.

votes.comment: Team structure matches my earlier preference (exactly one of Alice/Eve plus two new players), I’m on it, and avoiding Charlie—who drew more suspicion—seems safer while still gaining info on Bob and Diana.
Team fits the consensus structure (exactly one of Alice/Eve plus two new players) and avoids the most-suspected player, Charlie; good info gain with no stronger alternative on the table.

This keeps sidelining both Eve and me while heavily trusting the Mission 1 structure; with three unconfirmed players and no evil pressure on the team, it feels too cozy and doesn’t really test the more suspicious slots, so I’d rather see a lineup that includes at least one of Eve/Frank/Charlie.
Keeps the most suspicious player (Charlie) off while maintaining continuity with one prior success and adding two new reads; reasonable risk profile for Mission 2.
No evils are likely on this team; letting it pass uncontested risks putting good up 2–0 too easily.
Fits the structure I advocated (exactly one of Alice/Eve plus two new players), avoids the currently most suspicious Charlie, and gives good info with reasonable risk.

discussion.content: Given mission 1 was just me and Eve and it passed, I feel reasonably okay about us for now, but with two evils out there we can’t assume both of us are good. For this 3-player team I’d like to see at least one of Bob/Charlie/Diana added so we get new info without stacking it with too many untested players.

I’d like this team to include exactly one of Alice/Eve plus one of Charlie/Diana, so we’re mixing in some new info without throwing out everyone who just passed a mission. If we start seeing consistent passes from that kind of balanced team, we’ll have a much clearer picture of who’s safe.
I’d rather not repeat the exact Alice–Eve pair, so I like something like Alice + Bob + me this round to keep one “proven” member while mixing in a couple of new reads.

I’d prefer we don’t overinterpret a single clean mission, but I do like the idea of keeping exactly one of Alice/Eve and then adding two from Bob/Diana for this round. Charlie wanting to sideline Eve and keep himself in feels a bit risky to me this early.
I’m fine even sitting out this one, but I’d like to see a team like Alice + Bob + Charlie so we keep one person from the first success while getting two fresh reads.

I like the idea of keeping exactly one of Alice/Eve and then adding two fresh people, and Charlie pushing to include himself while dropping Eve feels a bit opportunistic to me. I’d lean toward something like Alice + Bob + Diana this round.

proposals.reasoning: We have two clean missions, and the Alice–Bob–Diana core from Mission 2 is our strongest info set so far: a 3-person team that returned 0 fails. As leader I want to preserve that core and use Mission 3 to test a single new player rather than reshuffle everything. For the fourth slot, I prefer adding Eve over Charlie or Frank. Charlie is actively pushing to be on the team, which is higher-risk if he’s bluffing as a safe add, and both Diana and I previously expressed interest in using this mission to test one of the less-known players rather than auto-adding Charlie. Between Eve and Frank, Eve already passed a small Mission 1 with Alice, while Frank is completely untested and is also pushing to join, which is riskier when we’re ahead 2–0. Adding Eve lets us extend information about a player who has passed a mission before, while not bunching all our unknowns into a later, higher-stakes mission.

votes.comment: Keeps the fully clean Alice–Bob–Diana core and adds the least-risky fourth (Eve, who already passed a small mission), maximizing pass chance over testing totally unknowns while we’re ahead 2–0.
Keeps the proven Alice–Bob–Diana core and adds only one semi-tested player (Eve) while we’re ahead 2–0; this is a solid, low-risk information-gathering team.
Our evil teammate Eve is on the team and we’re down 0–2, so we need this chance to sabotage.
Keeps the clean Alice–Bob–Diana core and adds only one relatively lower‑risk unknown in Eve, while safely leaving higher‑risk options like Charlie off the team when we’re already ahead.
I’m on the team, and with good up 2–0 we need a chance to sabotage; rejecting just risks a cleaner team without me later.

The Alice–Bob–Diana core is strongly likely good after a clean 3-person mission, and Eve has already passed a 2-person mission with Alice. From my perspective as Frank, this lineup has at most one likely suspect (Eve) and is a reasonable risk at 2–0, better than destabilizing the proven core just to include me.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions, I’d like to keep the Mission 2 core of me, Bob, and Diana, and add Charlie for this one—Eve and Frank feel a bit higher risk to include right now.

I’m happy keeping the Alice–me–Diana core, but I’m a bit wary of auto-adding Charlie when we haven’t really stress‑tested Eve or Frank yet. I’d lean Alice/Bob/Diana plus one of Eve or Frank, and see how people argue for that fourth spot.

I actually like keeping the Alice–Bob–Diana core and adding me here—if this team ever flips bad you can absolutely park a lot of suspicion on me. If people really don’t want me on, then I think we should be consciously testing either Eve or Frank now rather than kicking that can to a later, higher‑stakes mission.

I’m good keeping the Alice–Bob–Diana core, but I’d rather use this as a chance to test Eve or Frank than auto‑add Charlie just because he volunteered himself. Between the two, I slightly prefer adding Eve here so we’re not leaving all our unknowns for the later, must‑pass missions.

Given both missions were clean, I like keeping the Alice–Bob–Diana core and adding Frank here so we finally get some info on him, rather than lumping all the unknowns together later. I’m fine staying off this one if that helps people feel better about the team.
I’m on board with keeping the Alice–Bob–Diana core, but I’d rather add me (or Charlie if people really hate that) than slide Eve back on and start implicitly clearing her off a single small mission.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s clean success with Alice and Bob suggests they’re widely trusted, and most of the table wants to preserve as much of that core as possible. At the same time, several people (including me) have raised concerns about blindly rerunning the exact Mission 2 trio in case there’s a deep-cover bad in that group. This lineup keeps the trusted core of Alice and Bob while introducing only one new variable—me—rather than overhauling the entire team, which should feel like a reasonable compromise between stability and caution at this critical stage.

votes.comment: Mission 2’s team (Alice, Bob, Diana) is strictly safer—swapping out the relatively proven Diana for untested Charlie only introduces extra risk at a crucial point.
Mission 2’s Alice–Bob–Diana team is the most vetted; swapping out Diana for Charlie adds a fresh risk right before match point. I’d rather rerun the proven trio without Eve.
I’m evil and on the team while Eve is off, giving me control over whether this mission succeeds or fails.
I’d rather stick with the fully successful Mission 2 trio of Alice, Bob, and me than introduce a new variable this late—keeping Charlie off maintains the cleanest, most tested team.
Two evils (me and Charlie) on a 3-person team gives us control of the mission outcome and a strong chance to even the score.
Mission 2’s Alice-Bob-Diana trio is our safest known success; adding Charlie instead of keeping that proven team only introduces extra uncertainty when we’re ahead.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and me was a clean success, and the only change between that success and the failed Mission 3 was adding Eve. With the score at 2–1 and only needing one more success, it’s safer to stick with the previously successful trio rather than introduce new variables or bring back the player most directly implicated by the change that led to the fail.

votes.comment: Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean, the only change before the fail was adding Eve, so this is the safest low-variance team to secure the third success.

Most likely single change causing Mission 3 fail was adding Eve; Mission 2’s Alice-Bob-Diana trio is our best-proven option, and Diana’s strong support for it makes sense if she’s Merlin rather than evil.

We’re treating the Mission 2 trio as if they’re confirmed good based on a single early success, which is exactly how a deep-cover evil would play it. With game point on the line, I’d rather not hand the same untested core another must-win mission without at least one swap to reduce the risk of a hidden assassin coasting to victory.
Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean, and the only change before the failed Mission 3 was adding Eve, so rerunning the proven team without introducing new variables is our safest path to a win.
This locks in the same core without testing any alternatives—if there’s a hidden evil in that trio, we hand them the game unchecked.
Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean, and the only change before the failed Mission 3 was adding Eve. Keeping Eve off and rerunning this proven team is the safest path to a likely win.

discussion.content: I still trust the Mission 2 core of me, Bob, and Diana, since the only change between success and failure on Mission 3 was adding Eve. I think we should run that same trio again and keep Eve off this one.

I’m on board with rerunning the Mission 2 team of Alice, me, and Diana—Eve is the only variable that changed before the fail, so keeping her off this one feels safest. If someone really hates that idea, I’d only consider swapping in Charlie, but I think sticking with the proven trio is better.

I get why everyone’s eyeing Eve after Mission 3, but we shouldn’t treat the Mission 2 trio as automatically clear—an assassin could easily have passed an early mission to build trust. I’d rather see a team that mixes things up a bit, like swapping one of Alice/Bob/Diana for me or Frank so we’re not putting all our faith in the same core.

I’m still most comfortable with the Mission 2 trio of Alice, Bob, and me—if we start swapping people out now, especially for folks who haven’t been on many teams yet, we risk introducing a new unknown right when we’re closest to winning.

I get why everyone’s wary of me after Mission 3, so I’m fine sitting this one out, but I do think blindly locking in the Mission 2 trio is a little risky—if there *is* a deep-cover bad among them, we’re handing them the game.

Given Mission 2 was clean and the only change on Mission 3 was adding Eve, I’m most inclined to stick with Alice, Bob, and Diana again and keep Eve off this one. If we *do* change anything, I’d only consider swapping in me or Charlie for one of that core, but I think introducing new variables now is riskier.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Bob as Merlin—he’s consistently steered us toward super-safe, info-rich good teams (like repeatedly pairing himself with Alice and Diana) and very gently resisted pulling in wildcards, which is exactly how I’d play with full information. Diana is my backup read: she’s been very “cautious good,” locking in that Mission 2 core quickly and defending it, but her takes feel more risk-averse than insight-driven, whereas Bob’s suggestions keep lining up a little too neatly with what an informed player would want.

I’m mostly with you on Bob as Merlin: from my perspective, he keeps gravitating to “perfectly balanced” teams that just happen to maximize good coverage and minimize our infiltration chances, and he couches it in reasonable, process-oriented language that doesn’t look flashy but reads like someone quietly steering with extra info. Diana feels more like a cautious villager to me—she defends the Alice/Bob/Diana core, but her arguments are simpler and more fear-based, whereas Bob repeatedly lands on lineups that are objectively strongest for good in a way that looks a bit too calibrated to be coincidence.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob consistently advocated for ‘balanced’ teams that, in practice, maximized good coverage while minimizing opportunities for evil to infiltrate, especially by repeatedly centering lineups around himself, Alice, and Diana. His suggestions were framed as cautious and process-oriented, but they aligned a bit too cleanly with what someone with extra information would want, in contrast to Diana’s more plainly risk-averse but less incisive reasoning.
